message.content: We refer to PubMed articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), which is confirmed by echocardiography. In TOF, the degree of right ventricular outflow obstruction is most responsible for the patient's cyanosis, as it leads to decreased pulmonary blood flow and mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings support the diagnosis of Tetralogy of Fallot, which involves a ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and aortic override. The most responsible factor for the patient’s cyanosis is the degree of right ventricular outflow obstruction. This causes decreased pulmonary blood flow and increases the amount of deoxygenated blood that enters the systemic circulation, leading to cyanosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest Tetralogy of Fallot, which includes right ventricular outflow obstruction as one of its four components. This obstruction leads to mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood, resulting in cyanosis. The degree of RV hypertrophy, VSD size, and degree of aortic override are also important factors in this disease, but are not directly responsible for the cyanosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a congenital heart defect, and the presence of a systolic ejection murmur and a single S2 indicate pulmonary valve stenosis with decreased blood flow to the lungs. The degree of right ventricular outflow obstruction is the most responsible for cyanosis because it limits the amount of oxygenated blood that reaches the body. The other options are also factors in congenital heart defects, but they are not the most responsible for cyanosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the newborn has tetralogy of Fallot. The cyanosis is likely caused by the degree of right ventricular outflow obstruction, which leads to decreased pulmonary blood flow and oxygenation. The other options are also factors in the diagnosis, but do not primarily contribute to the cyanosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and diagnosis suggest Tetralogy of Fallot. The most responsible factor for cyanosis is the degree of right ventricular outflow obstruction, leading to decreased pulmonary blood flow and increased deoxygenated blood in the systemic circulation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting symptoms of cyanosis while crying, indicating a decrease in oxygen saturation. The presence of a systolic ejection murmur and a single S2 also suggest a congenital heart defect. The most likely diagnosis is Tetralogy of Fallot, which includes right ventricular outflow obstruction as a major factor responsible for cyanosis. The other options (right ventricular hypertrophy, ventricular septal defect, and aortic override) are also part of Tetralogy of Fallot but do not directly cause cyanosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest a diagnosis of tetralogy of Fallot. The most responsible factor for the patient's cyanosis is the degree of right ventricular outflow obstruction, which results in deoxygenated blood being shunted from the right to the left side of the heart and then to the rest of the body, causing cyanosis. The size of the ventricular septal defect and degree of aortic override are also important factors in the pathophysiology of tetralogy of Fallot, but they are not the most responsible for the patient's cyanosis.

We refer to the Mayo Clinic website for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest Tetralogy of Fallot. The degree of right ventricular outflow obstruction is most responsible for the patient's cyanosis. This obstruction limits the amount of blood that can flow to the lungs, resulting in reduced oxygenation and cyanosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest congenital heart disease, specifically tetralogy of Fallot. The most responsible factor for cyanosis in this condition is the degree of right ventricular outflow obstruction.
